Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of male cult follower wearing festival wreath headdress and possibly a beard, with right arm raised above head. Head and top left part of body only. Mould-made and hollow with crude back. White (gypsum?) coating, with traces of pink paint on headdress. Brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably made in Naukratis. A similar unprovenanced fragment of Harpocrates riding a duck was associated with 2nd century BC parallels (Török 1995, no.88). However this very fragmentary piece lacks diagnostic features to make dating certain. Török, L. 1995, Hellenistic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt, Roma.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.570) (Phase 1)
